data.title: G.V. WRONG; Judge bans TD from the road & fines him EUR900.

Byline: NIALL MOONAN

SHAMED drink-drive deputy GV Wright was yesterday fined EUR900 and banned from the road for two years - and then said he hoped others learned from his mistake.

The North Dublin TD, 56, was arrested after hitting a woman as he drove his 02-reg car last September.

Yesterday, he also had his licence endorsed by Judge James Scally in Dublin District Court.

Wright said afterwards he hoped that media coverage of the case might have a positive effect on other drivers.

He told reporters: "It may give other people an opportunity to change their habits, especially with Christmas coming up.

"I very much regret the incident."

Nurse Anne Butler, 50, was knocked down by Wright but she was not named in court yesterday.

She told the Irish Mirror after the smash: "I thought I was dead. I remember spinning up in the air. I came down off the bonnet and then on to the concrete."

The TD, from Malahide, who arrived in court dressed in a navy suit shortly after 10am, was named as Thomas Wright.

Garda Fergal Flynn gave evidence of arresting the TD when gardai were called to a road accident at North Strand Road on September 18.

He said there was a strong smell of alcohol when he spoke to Wright who admitted driving under the influence.

The deputy was arrested and taken to Store Street Garda station where his blood alcohol limit was registered at 67mg per 100mg.

The court heard Wright is a married father-of-three with no previous convictions.

Judge Scally said the reading was "very high" and imposed the fine, disqualification and licence endorsement.

As he walked from court afterwards, Wright refused to answer questions on whether he would resign from his seat.

CAPTION(S):

COURT: GV Wright yesterday
